bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, June 24, 1953

div1.p: Tate thinks that Truby's breakdown of the Camp Lazear costs is excellent. Their only point of disagreement involves confusion over the names Fernandez and Martinez.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, June 24, 1953
div1.p:
Thank you for sending me the final copy of the Camp Lazear
cost-sheet. I had intended asking you for a copy for myself,
so I appreciate your thoughtfulness.

I cannot say much more of the final copy other than what I
wrote you previously. It is indeed, an excellent break-down
of costs. In my opinion it is just as well presented as any
professional accounting firm could produce.

I still cannot see where I have helped you except in support-
ing your memories, which mostly coincide with mine. I suppose
there will never be a way to figure out those payroll checks
in your Table VI.

No, I do not think that you have “overplayed the value of
the check-book.” It was of incalculable help in this matter.
It decided for me the one point where our views don't coincide.--
The Martinez-Fernandez mix-up. I cannot see that it will be
of any use to anyone now, but I may send you my views on that,
just so you will understand why I have arrived at a different
conclusion regarding it.

I am quite sure that Doctor Hench will be highly pleased with
your paper, as it will surely be of value to him as you give
him your intimate knowledge of first-hand information.

Thanking you again and assuring you that I, too, have enjoyed
digging into those old figures you so kindly permitted me to
share with you. With best wishes for you and family,
